comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: PHOTO 1 - EUREKA ! At last I think I have a definite location - from the north end of DARLING ISLAND looking SOUTH across Pyrmont Bay to Pyrmont in the distance. Most of those buildings in the left distance were resumed and demolished soon after this photo (1904). The 'white' building is Boylan's Hotel on the site of its replacement, the Pyrmont Bridge Hotel. The steep ramp on to the new Pyrmont Bridge is just in front of the gabled building at far left. The wharf buildings are a new wheat storage and loading wharf. Evidently there was a bumper crop in 1903. The chimney belongs to the Pyrmont Power Station (not Ultimo), and acrobat Melvin Vaniman photographed a panorama looking the reverse direction from the top of the chimney in December 1903, presumably just before it started belching smoke. Vaniman panorama (which makes sense of my rant) - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemPopLarger.aspx?itemid=412343 , and State Library blurb - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=412343 . 1895 Map of area - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... Another contemporary photo of the background Pyrmont to compare buildings with Zoomit - from.ph/28399 There are several pictures available via a "Darling island" search on Trove, showing these warehouses stacked with grain sacks as are being loaded in Photo 1. I think the "Sol" was transporting the Government photographer (was it John Degotardi Jnr?). I wonder what he was standing on - another ship?

comment._content: Description of the bumper harvest of 1903-4 and the record number of ships in port (22/01/1904), including reference to French ships - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14594761 . Vivid description of the Darling Island wheat wharf (SMH 22/01/1904) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14594793

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I am confused by your explanation.   You are at Darling Island looking south to Pyrmont ??  Darling Island is at Pyrmont.  Its not a far shore which looks the best part of a mile away.  Do you mean,  you are looking south along Darling Harbour up towards Railway Square ?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: @mich_sydney_2007 - have a look at beachcomberaustralia's links and also his notes on the photo. It should then make more sense. He's even identified a building in Pyrmont. There's a larger image you can view in all sizes which may make things a bit clearer.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ mich_sydney-2007 - We were ALL confused (see the blog comments) - so much has changed before and since 1904 - but I am not sure I can explain it better than above. By "across Pyrmont Bay to Pyrmont" I mean the area of Pyrmont near Union Street and Pyrmont Bridge Road. The photographer was near "Ballarat Park" as marked on Google Maps, looking (almost) south - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+... . That is about 1km or 1/2 a mile from Pyrmont Bridge. The Vaniman panorama (link above) shows this clearly imho. The old 1895 map shows some of the old features. The Powerhouse Museum photo is great for identifying buildings like Boylan's Hotel. While this may confuse further, here is another (1905) map of the area (upside down S-N) - it shows a couple of wharfs in Pyrmont Bay which were not built at the time of this photo, but also the railway lines on Darling Island- www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f115-sd&rgn=0.5... I too thought it was Darling Harbour towards Railway Square, but could not reconcile those buildings in the background. I am still unsure about the 'spire', but I think it might have been part of the Public School in Murray Street. Persevere!

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I think the 'new' photo is minutes EARLIER.  The tug is pushing the empty (see waterline) ship into the wharf to be loaded.  You can see the white bow in the top photo behind the first ship, in a veritable forest of masts,  

If a tug is pushing, is it still a tug?

comment.author: 47201412@N02

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You old sea dog! My ship captain great-great-great-grandfather just rolled over in his grave in embarrassment. :)

A tug is a tug is a tug ... But they rarely tug do they? Maybe they should be called a nudge!
